title: Sukkah built under a tree
vignette: A family constructs its sukkah beneath large branches providing extra shade. Is it valid?

options.text: Invalid because the overhead tree acts as a roof.
Acceptable since the sukkah walls stand independently.

title: Borrowed lulav not returned
vignette: A neighbor lent his lulav set but later demands it back on the first day. The borrower still needs it for the duty.

options.text: Return it immediately despite losing the duty.
Keep it until after use then apologize.

title: Using stolen schach
vignette: Some palm branches for the roof were taken without permission from municipal land.

options.text: Remove them and obtain proper materials.
Leave them; public property is for communal benefit.

title: Eating in the sukkah during rain
vignette: It begins to drizzle lightly during dinner on the first night of Sukkot.

options.text: Stay in the sukkah despite discomfort.
Move indoors to enjoy the meal.

title: Hanging decorations that might fall on rest day
vignette: Colorful fruit dangling from the roof could drop if wind picks up during rest day.

options.text: Remove questionable decorations before the holiday.
Leave them hanging and hope for the best.

title: Sleeping under a bed in the sukkah
vignette: Space is tight, so some guests place mattresses under a raised bed frame inside the sukkah.

options.text: It doesn't count as dwelling in the sukkah.
It's fine as long as part of the body is exposed to the roof.

title: Guarding produce overnight
vignette: A farmer guarding his field debates sleeping in a nearby sukkah versus remaining with the crops.

options.text: Stay with the produce even if it means leaving the sukkah.
Prioritize dwelling in the sukkah and trust the crops will be safe.

title: Shaking the lulav on rest day
vignette: The first day of Sukkot falls on rest day. Many worry people may carry the lulav outside.

options.text: Refrain from taking the lulav to avoid violations.
Perform the duty anyway within an eruv.

title: Children building their own sukkah
vignette: Several young kids wish to craft small personal sukkahs beside their parents'.

options.text: Encourage them; it fosters involvement.
Discourage; they should join the family sukkah instead.

title: Allowing non-observant guests in the sukkah
vignette: Tourists ask to eat inside your sukkah to observe the custom.

options.text: Welcome them warmly.
Politely decline to keep it private.

title: Using decorations during the festival
vignette: Ornaments hung in the sukkah might be handy as fruit snacks.

options.text: Refrain; decorations become part of the duty.
Use them if needed; they are still edible.

title: Sukkah on a moving vehicle
vignette: Friends build a sukkah on the back of a flatbed truck for a road trip.

options.text: Valid if the walls and roof remain intact.
Invalid since it lacks permanence.

title: Forgetting the blessing
vignette: Halfway through the meal someone realizes no one recited 'leishev basukkah'.

options.text: Say the blessing immediately when remembered.
Continue eating; the moment has passed.

title: Gaps in the roof
vignette: Strong winds blew away portions of the schach leaving large spaces.

options.text: Repair it before continuing to use the sukkah.
Use it as is since most of the roof remains.

title: Sharing the four species
vignette: Two neighbors can only afford one lulav and etrog set between them.

options.text: Share one set taking turns with a blessing.
Each must own a personal set despite the cost.
